appinfo.html:p:
JCAMP-DX identifiers may not match with XML identifiers. When JCAMP-DX LABELS are parsed, alphabetic characters are converted to upper case, and all spaces, dashes, slashes, and underlines are discarded. (XUNITS, xunits, xUNITS, and X-UNITS are all equivalent JCAMP-DX labels.) The following transformation rules apply when mapping JCAMP-DX identifiers onto identifiers in this dictionary:
Any spaces are removed
A '.' character as first characted is replaced by the technique abbreviation followed by an underscore, e.g. .SHIFTREFERENCE by NMR_SHIFTREFERENCE

entry.definition: The JCAMP-DX versions 4.24, 5.0, 5.01
entry.description: JCAMP-DX 4.24 for IR was published in 1988, 5.0 for NMR in 1993 and MS in 1994 and 5.01 for NMR in 1999, IMS in 2001 and EMR in 2006

entry.definition: 3.7 (version number)
4.24, 5.00, 5.01 (version number)
description of the spectrum
The data type of the spectrum
entry.description: Can hold the following values: INFRARED SPECTRUM, RAMAN SPECTRUM, INFRARED PEAK TABLE, INFRARED INTERFEROGRAM, INFRARED TRANSFORMED SPECTRUM, NMR FID, NMR SPECTRUM, NMR PEAK TABLE, NMR PEAK ASSIGNMENTS, MASS SPECTRUM, CONTINUOUS MASS SPECTRUM, ION MOBILITY SPECTRUM, IMS PEAK TABLE, IMS PEAK ASSIGNMENTS, EMR MEASUREMENT, EMR SIMULATION
XYDATA, XYPOINTS, PEAK TABLE, ASSIGNMENTS, NTUPLES

entry.definition: Abscissa units
entry.description: Specifies the abscissa units for XYDATA, the following entries are allowed: 1/CM, MICROMETERS, NANOMETERS, SECONDS, HZ, M/Z (PPM allowed for assignments and tables but NOT for spectra) MILLISECONDS, MICROSECONDS, NANOSECONDS, DEGREE, HERTZ, KELVIN, SECOND, TESLA, WATT.

entry.definition: Ordinate units
entry.description: Specifies the ordinate units for XYDATA, the following entries are allowed: TRANSMITTANCE, REFLECTANCE, ABSORBANCE, KUBELKA-MUNK, COUNTS, RELATIVE ABUNBDANCE, MICROAMPERES, NANOAMPERES, PICOAMPERES, ARBITRARY UNITS

entry.definition: Factor by which x-components of XYDATA are multiplied to obtain actual values
Factor by which y-components of XYDATA are multiplied to obtain actual values
entry.description: YFactor is normally chosen to convert Y-values to integers to save space required by decimal points, e.g. if transmittance is recorded between 0 and 0.9999 use a YFACTOR to give 0 - 9999.

entry.definition: First recorded abscissa value (for NMR actual value may be affected by ShiftReference)
Last recorded abscissa value (for NMR actual value may be affected by ShiftReference)
Actual Y-value corresponding to FIRSTX.
entry.description: FIRSTY should equal YFACTOR times the first Y-value in XYDATA

entry.definition: Largest x value
Smallest x value
Largest y value
Smallest y value
The nominal spacing between points
entry.description: This LDR gives the nominal spacing between points for inspection by the user. Actual X-values are calculated from the spacing by (LASTX-FIRSTX)/(NPOINTS-1))

entry.definition: Number of components of XYDATA, XYPOINTS, PEAKTABLE or RADATA
The actual data is encoded in here
entry.description: Contains the table of ordinates at equal X-intervals. Will extend over many lines.

entry.definition: Contains a table of XY pairs for spectral data which are not spaced at constant abscissa increments. (XY..XY)
List of peak assignments for components, functional groups, etc. (XA) or (XYA) or (XYWA) (A = <assignment>)
(XY..XY), (XYW..XYW) or (XYM..XYM) (M = multiplicity)
Specifies the Coblentz Class of the spectrum (1,2,3 or 4) and the IUPAC Class of digital representation (A,B,C)
Name of organization, address, telephone number, name of individual contributor, etc., as appropriate.
Name of owner of a proprietary spectrum
entry.description: The organization or person named under ORIGIN is responsible for accuracy of this field. If data is copyrighted, this line should read "COPYRIGHT (C) (year) by (name)".

entry.definition: Date when the spectrum was measured, in the form YY/MM/DD.
Time when the spectrum was measured, in the form HH/MM/SS.
the long date format is YYYY/MM/DD [HH/MM/SS] [+/-UUUU], where UUUU is time zone difference to GMT.
Adequate identification to locate the original spectrum, ie., name of file containing the spectrum, or library name and serial number of the spectrum.
Reference to additional spectra
entry.description: Cross reference refer to additional spectra of the same sample, i.e., different thickness, mulling agent, polarization, temperature, time, etc. or serve to link a peak table or interferogram with a spectrum

entry.definition: Decription of the sample.
entry.description: If the sample is not a pure compound, this field should contain its description, i.e, compositon, origin, appearance, result of interpretion, etc. If the sample is a known compund, the following entries should specify structure an properties, as appropriate.

entry.definition: The chemical abstracts compliant name.
entry.description: Name according to Chemical Abstracts naming conventions as described in the 1985 CAS Index Guide. Examples can be found in Chemical Abstracts indices or the Merck Index.

entry.definition: Common trade or other names.
Molecular formula.
entry.description: Element symbols are arranged with carbon first, followed by hydrogen, and the remaining element symbols in alphabetic order.

entry.definition: substance name in IUPAC form
CAS Registry Number.
The Wiswesser line notation is a precise and concise means of expressing structural formulae as character strings.
The Beilstein Lawson Number is a structural formula clustering code based on the Beilstein System.
entry.description: Is used for locating information in Beilstein databases, including STN online database. The code contains only structural information and can be locally generated.

entry.definition: Boiling point in degrees C.
melting point in degrees C
Sample pressure in appropriate units if significantly different from atmospheric pressure.
Sample temperature in degrees C if significantly different from room temperature.
State of the compound.
entry.description: Solid, liquid, gas, solution, KBr pellet, powder, nujol mull, etc. in infrared spectroscopy

entry.definition: In the form: ND = 1542^20 (index at 20 C for NaD line).
Density in g/cm^3.
Molecular weight.
List of components and impurities and their concentrations.
description of the solvent
Contains the manufacturers name, model of the spectrometer, software system, and release number, as appropriate, in the form used by the manufacturer.
List of pertinent instrumental settings.
Sampling procedure.
entry.description: First entry should be MODE of observation (transmission, specular reflection, PAS, matrix isolation, photothermal beam deflection, etc.), followed by appropriate additional information, i.e., name and model of accessories, cell thickness, and window material for fixed liquid cells, ATR plate material...

entry.definition: Nominal resolution in units specified by XUNITS.
Pathlength in cm.
Description of background correction, smoothing, substraction, deconvolution procedures, apodization function, zero-fill, or other data processing.
label of the X-axis
label of the Y-axis
list of audit trail entries in the form: (id no., <longdate >, <who>, <where>, <what> )
number of blocks enclosed in a link block of a compound file
a unique positive integer assigned to each block in a compound file used as a block identifier
data stored in PAGE format
end of section
each PAGE holds a spectrum usually with similar xValues.

entry.description: (X++(R..R)) or (X++(I..I)), XYDATA

entry.definition: number of data points of the corresponding axis
data form: AFFN or ASDF
variable name, e.g.: TIME, FID/REAL, FID/IMAG, PAGE NUMBER, MASS, INTENSITY, RETENTION TIME
INDEPENDENT DEPENDENT PAGE
factor to convert scaled values of the corresponding axis to actual values
first unscaled value of the corresponding axis in the belonging UNITS
last unscaled value of the corresponding axis in the belonging UNITS
largest unscaled value of the corresponding axis in the belonging UNITS
smallest unscaled value of the corresponding axis in the belonging UNITS
symbol to indicate an axis, e.g.: X, Y, R, I, T, N
units belonging to the values of the corresponding axis, e.g.: SECONDS, ARBITRARY UNITS, M/Z, RELATIVE ABUNDANCE
There are a wide variety of experimental methods used in EMR.
entry.description: Can hold the following values: ADMR, CIDEP, COSY, CYCLOPS, DECENT, DEER, DEFENCE, DONUT, ELDOR, EPR, ESR, ESR-STM, ESE, ESEEM, EXSCY, FDMR, FMR, FORTE, HETEROCOSY, HFEPR, HYEND, HYSCORE, LEFE, LODESR, LOD-PEPR, LOD-ESEEM, LOMENDOR, MARY, MAS-EPR, MODR, MQ-EPR, MQ-ELDOR, MQ-ENDOR, NZ-ESEEM, PCDMR, PEANUT, PEDRI, PYESR, RAS-EPR, RYDMR, SECSY, SEDOR, SEESR, SIFTER, SMART, TREPR, TRFDMR

entry.definition: either continuous wave or one or more pulses are used to perturb the sample
entry.description: CW or PULSE

entry.definition: Used where a resonator is not involved in the measurement
Typical EMR experiments are conducted at a fixed microwave frequency that ranges from few MHz to hundreds of GHz. (in Hz)
Power of the microwave source (in W)
Phase of the microwave source (in degree)
Frequency for the second microwave source. (in Hz required for ELDOR)
Power of the second microwave source (in W)
Phase of the second microwave source (in degree)
In a typical CW EMR experiment, the signal can be modulated by either field or frequency to achieve the enhancement of the signal resolution. The source of the modulation is required for CW.
Amplitude of the corresponding modulation unit.
Frequency of modulation unit (Hz).
Scalar factor (gain) that is applied to the detection signal.
The typical CW experiment is recorded in 1st harmonic but may be 2nd or 3rd etc.
Phase-sensitive detection is the common technique for EMR experiments and is often calibrated to 0 degrees relative to the reference arm.
Time required to complete one scan of the spectrum (s).
Total number of scans for a spectrum. (1 if a single scan)
Assumes a single circle goniometer (degree).
A static magnetic field is commonly used when carrying out double resonance or spin echo experiments (T)
In a double resonance experiment, say ENDOR, a constant power of RF source that was used to scan for nuclear transitions (W).
In a double resonance experiment, say ENDOR, frequency of the RF source used to scan for nuclear transitions (Hz).
In a double resonance experiment, say ENDOR, power of the RF source used to scan for nuclear transitions (W).
In a triple resonance experiment, frequency of the RF source used for the third source (in Hz).
In a triple resonance experiment, power of the RF source used for the third source.
For EMR imaging experiments, intensity of the gradient magnetic field along the theta angle (using spherical coordinates) (T).
For EMR imaging experiments, intensity of the gradient magnetic field along the phi angle (using spherical coordinates) (T).
For EMR imaging experiments, intensity of the total angular gradient magnetic field (using spherical coordinates) (T).
For EMR imaging experiments, intensity of the gradient magnetic field along the X axis. (T).
For EMR imaging experiments, intensity of the gradient magnetic field along the Y axis. (T).
For EMR imaging experiments, intensity of the gradient magnetic field along the Z axis. (T).
Sources or tools used to simulate the spectrum (e.g., QPOW, Bruker, WinEPR, etc.)

Detailed descriptions of the EMR parameters that are needed to reproduce the simulated spectra such as microwave frequency, hyperfine coupling constants, rotation angles, static magnetic fields, scan range, linewidth, etc.
the resonator (also known as the cavity) is used to hold the sample
The time constant is an output filter that utilizes a resistive-capacitive filter to filter the output of the phase-sensitive detector to improve the signal to noise.
The chemical standard used internally or externally to calibrate the g value of an EMR signal. (e.g.,DPPH or MgO).
Numerical offset of the global X axis.
Numerical offset of the global X axis.
description of the carrier gas
carrier gas flow in the ionization [and in the drift chamber] in L/min
water concentration in the carrier gas in ppm
drift chamber geometry: RECT, length, width, height or CYL, length, radius in mm
description of the drift gas (if used)
drift gas flow into the drift chamber in L/min
electric field in the ionisation and in the drift chamber in V/cm
ionization chamber geometry: RECT, length, width, height or CYL, length, radius in mm
ionization energy in eV

entry.description: UV, BR, AL, PD, CD, ESI, LI, LD, SI, or SY

entry.definition: description of the ionization source

entry.description: POSITIVE or NEGATIVE

entry.definition: pressure inside the IMS system in kPa
temperature in the ionization [and in the drift chamber] in degrees C
(K0, A) (K0 in cm^2 V^-1 s^-1), A = <assignment>)
time between shutter openings in ms
voltage between the wires of the shutter in V
shutter opening time in microsecond
Accelerating voltage in V
base peak position in XUNITS
base peak intensity in COUNTS or VOLTS, units
mass of the most common isotopic peak in AMU
nominal mass of the molecule
retention time in seconds
reconstructed ion current in COUNTS
scan number
scan rate in SECONDS/DECADE or MASSES/SECOND, units
source temperature in degrees C
predefined list of spectometer types
entry.description: Possible Entries: B, EB, BE, Q, TRAP, TOF

entry.definition: total ion current in VOLTS or COUNTS, units
type of detector

entry.description: Possible entries: DIRECT, BATCH, GC, LC, CZE, PB, MOB

entry.definition: inlet temperature in degrees C
ionization energy in eV

entry.description: EI+ or EI-, Cl+ or Cl-, FAB+ or FAB-, TSP+ or TSP-, ESI+ or ESI-, APICI+ or APICI-, LD+ or LD-
Possible entries: SIMULTANEOUS, SINGLE, SEQUENTIAL

entry.definition: Acquisition range in AMU (first, last)
J (A,B) (coupling constant in Hz (Atom no. A, Hetero Atom no. B))
table of decoupler frequencies (F, 90) in MHz and decoupler 90 degree pulses in microsecond
RD, ID (preacquisition delay for real and imaginary values in microsecond)
digitizer resolution in bits (12, 16 etc.)
magnetic field strength in Tesla
filter width in Hz, description of filter algorithm
magic angle spinning frequency in HZ
used to represent maximum intensity used for peak picking
minimum intensity used for peak picking
90 degree observe pulse time in microsecond
observer frequency in MHz
observed nucleus e.g. ^13C
0 order phase correction in degrees
1st order phase correction in degrees per Hz relative to maximum X value
information concerning pulse squences, pulse delays, relaxation delays, pulse angles, etc
(XYR) (R = relaxation in seconds)
INTERNAL or EXTERNAL, name of ref. compound, data point number, shift value in ppm
solvent lock signal in ppm
sample spinning rate in Hz
no. of complex zero filling points
factor to convert scaled amplitude values to actual values
A fraction whose denominator is the number of possible aliases for a given sample and whose numerator is the number of the alias represented by the data.
should reflect amplifier gain, etc., to allow transmittance to be calculated as the ratio of sample to reference intensities.
unit of amplitude of interferograms (ARBITRARY UNITS, VOLTS)
first unscaled amplitude value in AUNITS, compare to FIRSTR
unscaled maximum amplitude of interferogram, in AUNITS
unscaled minimum amplitude of interferogram, in AUNITS
optical retardation per data point in RUNITS. A function of laser frequency and interferometer geometry.
first unscaled optical retardation value of an interferogram, in RUNITS
last unscaled optical retardation value of an interferogram, in RUNITS
Contains interferogram or transformed spectrum as a table of ordinates (A) vs. retardation (R), with equal R spacing. (R++(A..A))
factor to convert scaled optical retardation values to actual values
unit of optical retardation for interferograms (MICROMETERS)
zero path difference
AN AS NH (AtomNo., Atomic Symbol, No. of implicit Hydrogen atoms)
AN1 AN2 BT (AtomNo.1, AtomNo. 2, BondType)
CH AN1 AN2 etc. (Charge, AtomNo. 1, ... AtomNo. I)
maximum of absolute value of X or Y coordinates
maximum of the absolute value of either the X, Y or Z coordinates of the atoms
UE AN1 AN2 ... ANI (no. of Unpaired Electrons, AtomNo. 1 ... AtomNo. I)
AN SD SG (AtomNo., StereoDescriptor (P or M), StereoGroup)
YES
AN1 AN2 SD SG (AtomNo. 1, AtomNo. 2, StereoDescriptor (P, M or 0), StereoGroup)
AN X Y Z (AtomNo., coordinates for graphical representation of the structure)
AN X Y Z (AtomNo., physically meaningful coordinates)
factor used to scale the integer atom coordinates into the original Angstrom units
source of the 3D coordinates
